description.para: This adjustment function provides the logic for 'month-based' advancement on a ymd based calendar. The policy it uses to handle the non existant end of month days is to back up to the last day of the month. Also, if the starting date is the last day of a month, this functor will attempt to adjust to the end of the month.

header.name: boost/date_time/c_time.hpp

struct.name: c_time
struct.purpose: Provides a uniform interface to some 'ctime' functions.

description.para: Provides a uniform interface to some ctime functions and their '_r' counterparts. The '_r' functions require a pointer to a user created std::tm struct whereas the regular functions use a staticly created struct and return a pointer to that. These wrapper functions require the user to create a std::tm struct and send in a pointer to it. This struct may be used to store the resulting time. The returned pointer may or may not point to this struct, however, it will point to the result of the corresponding function. All functions do proper checking of the C function results and throw exceptions on error. Therefore the functions will never return NULL.

class.name: constrained_value
class.purpose: A template to specify a constrained basic value type.

description.para: This template provides a quick way to generate an integer type with a constrained range. The type provides for the ability to specify the min, max, and and error handling policy.

value policies A class that provides the range limits via the min and max functions as well as a function on_error that determines how errors are handled. A common strategy would be to assert or throw and exception. The on_error is passed both the current value and the new value that is in error.

class.name: date
class.purpose: Representation of timepoint at the one day level resolution.

description.para: The date template represents an interface shell for a date class that is based on a year-month-day system such as the gregorian or iso systems. It provides basic operations to enable calculation and comparisons.

This date representation fundamentally departs from the C tm struct approach. The goal for this type is to provide efficient date operations (add, subtract) and storage (minimize space to represent) in a concrete class. Thus, the date uses a count internally to represent a particular date. The calendar parameter defines the policies for converting the the year-month-day and internal counted form here. Applications that need to perform heavy formatting of the same date repeatedly will perform better by using the year-month-day representation.

Internally the date uses a day number to represent the date. This is a monotonic time representation. This representation allows for fast comparison as well as simplifying the creation of writing numeric operations. Essentially, the internal day number is like adjusted julian day. The adjustment is determined by the Epoch date which is represented as day 1 of the calendar. Day 0 is reserved for negative infinity so that any actual date is automatically greater than negative infinity. When a date is constructed from a date or formatted for output, the appropriate conversions are applied to create the year, month, day representations.

class.name: years_duration
class.purpose: additional duration type that represents a logical year

description.para: A logical year enables things like: "date(2002,Mar,2) + years(2) -> 2004-Mar-2". If the date is a last day-of-the-month, the result will also be a last-day-of-the-month (ie date(2001-Feb-28) + years(3) -> 2004-Feb-29).

description.para: Class that provides format based I/O facet for date types.
This class allows the formatting of dates by using format string. Format strings are:

listitem.para: A => long_weekday_format - Full name Ex: Tuesday
a => short_weekday_format - Three letter abbreviation Ex: Tue
B => long_month_format - Full name Ex: October
b => short_month_format - Three letter abbreviation Ex: Oct
x => standard_format_specifier - defined by the locale

description.para: Default month format == b Default weekday format == a

class.name: date_generator_formatter
class.purpose: Formats date_generators for output.

description.para:
Formatting of date_generators follows specific orders for the various types of date_generators.
partial_date => "dd Month"
nth_day_of_the_week_in_month => "nth weekday of month"
first_day_of_the_week_in_month => "first weekday of month"
last_day_of_the_week_in_month => "last weekday of month"
first_day_of_the_week_after => "weekday after"
first_day_of_the_week_before => "weekday before" While the order of the elements in these phrases cannot be changed, the elements themselves can be. Weekday and Month get their formats and names from the date_facet. The remaining elements are stored in the date_generator_formatter and can be customized upon construction or via a member function. The default elements are those shown in the examples above.

method.name: elements
method.purpose: Replace the set of phrase elements with those contained in new_strings.

description.para:
The order of the strings in the given collection is important. They must follow:
first, second, third, fourth, fifth, last, before, after, of.
It is not necessary to send in a complete set if only a few elements are to be replaced as long as the correct beg_pos is used.

Ex: To keep the default first through fifth elements, but replace the rest with a collection of:
"final", "prior", "following", "in". The beg_pos of date_generator_formatter::last would be used.

method.purpose: Put a partial_date => "dd Month".

method.purpose: Put a first_day_of_the_week_after => "weekday after".

description.para: Returns string formatted with up to 3 digits: Jan-01 == "0" Feb-29 == "58" Dec-31 == "365"

constructor.purpose: Partial date created from number of days into year. Range 1-366.

description.para: Allowable values range from 1 to 366. 1=Jan1, 366=Dec31. If argument exceeds range, partial_date will be created with closest in-range value. 60 will always be Feb29, if get_date() is called with a non-leap year an exception will be thrown

class.name: nth_kday_of_month
class.purpose: Useful generator functor for finding holidays.

description.para: Based on the idea in Cal. Calc. for finding holidays that are the 'first Monday of September'. When instantiated with 'fifth' kday of month, the result will be the last kday of month which can be the fourth or fifth depending on the structure of the month.

The algorithm here basically guesses for the first day of the month. Then finds the first day of the correct type. That is, if the first of the month is a Tuesday and it needs Wenesday then we simply increment by a day and then we can add the length of a week until we get to the 'nth kday'. There are probably more efficient algorithms based on using a mod 7, but this one works reasonably well for basic applications.

method.name: get_date
method.purpose: Return a concrete date when provided with a year specific year.

method.name: to_string
method.purpose: Returns string suitable for use in POSIX time zone string.

description.para: Returns a string formatted as "M4.3.0" ==> 3rd Sunday in April.

function.name: nth_as_str
function.purpose: Returns nth arg as string. 1 -> "first", 2 -> "second", max is 5.

function.name: days_until_weekday
function.purpose: Calculates the number of days until the next weekday.

description.para: Calculates the number of days until the next weekday. If the date given falls on a Sunday and the given weekday is Tuesday the result will be 2 days

function.name: days_before_weekday
function.purpose: Calculates the number of days since the previous weekday.

description.para: Calculates the number of days since the previous weekday If the date given falls on a Sunday and the given weekday is Tuesday the result will be 5 days. The answer will be a positive number because Tuesday is 5 days before Sunday, not -5 days before.

function.name: next_weekday
function.purpose: Generates a date object representing the date of the following weekday from the given date.

description.para: Generates a date object representing the date of the following weekday from the given date. If the date given is 2004-May-9 (a Sunday) and the given weekday is Tuesday then the resulting date will be 2004-May-11.

function.name: previous_weekday
function.purpose: Generates a date object representing the date of the previous weekday from the given date.

description.para: Generates a date object representing the date of the previous weekday from the given date. If the date given is 2004-May-9 (a Sunday) and the given weekday is Tuesday then the resulting date will be 2004-May-4.

class.name: date_itr_base

description.para: This class provides the skeleton for the creation of iterators. New and interesting interators can be created by plugging in a new function that derives the next value from the current state. generation of various types of -based information.
The date_type is a concrete date_type. The date_type must define a duration_type and a calendar_type.

define as_short_string and as_long_string
(see langer & kreft p334).

function.name: convert_to_lower
function.purpose: A function to replace the std::transform( , , ,tolower) construct.

description.para: This function simply takes a string, and changes all the characters in that string to lowercase (according to the default system locale). In the event that a compiler does not support locales, the old C style tolower() is used.

function.name: month_str_to_ushort
function.purpose: Helper function for parse_date.

function.name: find_match
function.purpose: Find index of a string in either of 2 arrays.

description.para: find_match searches both arrays for a match to 's'. Both arrays must contain 'size' elements. The index of the match is returned. If no match is found, 'size' is returned. Ex. "Jan" returns 0, "Dec" returns 11, "Tue" returns 2. 'size' can be sent in with: (greg_month::max)() (which 12), (greg_weekday::max)() + 1 (which is 7) or date_time::NumSpecialValues

function.name: parse_date
function.purpose: Generic function to parse a delimited date (eg: 2002-02-10)

description.para: Accepted formats are: "2003-02-10" or " 2003-Feb-10" or "2003-Feburary-10" The order in which the Month, Day, & Year appear in the argument string can be accomodated by passing in the appropriate ymd_order_spec

description.para: Time offset in the day for the local time
Local day offset for start of dst
Number of minutes to adjust clock forward

method.purpose: Check the local time offset when on dst start day.

description.para: On this dst transition, the time label between the transition boundary and the boudary + the offset are invalid times. If before the boundary then still not in dst.

description.para: Time offset in the day for the local time
Local time of day for end of dst

method.purpose: Check the local time offset when on the last day of dst.

description.para: This is the calculation for the DST end day. On that day times prior to the conversion time - dst_length (1 am in US) are still in dst. Times between the above and the switch time are ambiguous. Times after the start_offset are not in dst.

header.name: boost/date_time/filetime_functions.hpp
header.para: Function(s) for converting between a FILETIME structure and a time object. This file is only available on systems that have BOOST_HAS_FTIME defined.

description.para: The function converts file_time into number of microseconds elapsed since 1970-Jan-01

note.para: Only dates after 1970-Jan-01 are supported. Dates before will be wrapped.
The function is templated on the FILETIME type, so that it can be used with both native FILETIME and the ad-hoc boost::date_time::winapi::file_time type.

function.name: time_from_ftime
function.purpose: Create a time object from an initialized FILETIME struct.

description.para: Create a time object from an initialized FILETIME struct. A FILETIME struct holds 100-nanosecond units (0.0000001). When built with microsecond resolution the file_time's sub second value will be truncated. Nanosecond resolution has no truncation.

note.para: The function is templated on the FILETIME type, so that it can be used with both native FILETIME and the ad-hoc boost::date_time::winapi::file_time type.

class.name: format_date_parser
class.purpose: Class with generic date parsing using a format string.

description.para:
The following is the set of recognized format specifiers
a - Short weekday name
A - Long weekday name
b - Abbreviated month name
B - Full month name
d - Day of the month as decimal 01 to 31
j - Day of year as decimal from 001 to 366
m - Month name as a decimal 01 to 12
U - Week number 00 to 53 with first Sunday as the first day of week 1?
w - Weekday as decimal number 0 to 6 where Sunday == 0
W - Week number 00 to 53 where Monday is first day of week 1
x - facet default date representation
y - Year without the century - eg: 04 for 2004
Y - Year with century
The weekday specifiers (a and A) do not add to the date construction, but they provide a way to skip over the weekday names for formats that provide them.

todo -- Another interesting feature that this approach could provide is an option to fill in any missing fields with the current values from the clock. So if you have m-d the parser would detect the missing year value and fill it in using the clock.
todo -- What to do with the x. x in the classic facet is just bad...
Of all the objects that the format_date_parser can parse, only a date can be a special value. Therefore, only parse_date checks for special_values.

method.name: parse_month
method.purpose: Throws bad_month if unable to parse.

method.name: parse_month
method.purpose: Throws bad_month if unable to parse.

method.name: parse_day_of_month
method.purpose: Expects 2 digits 01-31. Throws bad_day_of_month if unable to parse.

method.name: parse_year
method.purpose: throws bad_year if unable to parse

method.name: parse_year

description.para: Will consume 'max_length' characters from stream only if those characters are digits. Returns '-1' if no number can be parsed. Will not parse a number preceeded by a '+' or '-'.

class.name: int_adapter
class.purpose: Adapter to create integer types with +-infinity, and not a value.

description.para: This class is used internally in counted date/time representations. It adds the floating point like features of infinities and not a number. It also provides mathmatical operations with consideration to special values following these rules: +infinity - infinity == Not A Number (NAN) infinity * non-zero == infinity infinity * zero == NAN +infinity * -integer == -infinity infinity / infinity == NAN infinity * infinity == infinity *

header.name: boost/date_time/local_time_adjustor.hpp
header.para: Time adjustment calculations for local times

class.name: utc_adjustment
class.purpose: Provides a base offset adjustment from utc.

class.name: dynamic_local_time_adjustor
class.purpose: Allow sliding utc adjustment with fixed dst rules.

method.name: utc_offset
method.purpose: Presumes local time.

class.name: static_local_time_adjustor
class.purpose: Embed the rules for local time adjustments at compile time.

method.name: utc_to_local_offset

description.para: UTC time to calculate offset to local time This adjustment depends on the following observations about the workings of the DST boundary offset. Since UTC time labels are monotonically increasing we can determine if a given local time is in DST or not and therefore adjust the offset appropriately.

method.purpose: Calculates the offset from a utc time to local based on dst and utc offset.

description.para: The logic is as follows. Starting with UTC time use the offset to create a label for an non-dst adjusted local time. Then call dst_rules::local_is_dst with the non adjust local time. The results of this function will either unabiguously decide that the initial local time is in dst or return an illegal or ambiguous result. An illegal result only occurs at the end of dst (where labels are skipped) and indicates that dst has ended. An ambiguous result means that we need to recheck by making a dst adjustment and then rechecking. If the dst offset is added to the utc time and the recheck proves non-ambiguous then we are past the boundary. If it is still ambiguous then we are ahead of the boundary and dst is still in effect.
TODO -- check if all dst offsets are positive. If not then the algorithm needs to check for this and reverse the illegal/ambiguous logic.

method.name: local_to_utc_offset
method.purpose: Get the offset to UTC given a local time.

class.name: local_adjustor
class.purpose: Template that simplifies the creation of local time calculator.

description.para: Use this template to create the timezone to utc convertors as required.
This class will also work for other regions that don't use dst and have a utc offset which is an integral number of hours.

struct.name: us_dst_trait

struct.name: eu_dst_trait
struct.purpose: Rules for daylight savings start in the EU (Last Sun in Mar)

description.para:
These amount to the following:
Start of dst day is last Sunday in March
End day of dst is last Sunday in Oct
Going forward switch time is 2:00 am (offset 120 minutes)
Going back switch time is 3:00 am (off set 180 minutes)
Shift duration is one hour (60 minutes)

struct.name: uk_dst_trait
struct.purpose: Alternative dst traits for some parts of the United Kingdom.

header.name: boost/date_time/microsec_time_clock.hpp
header.para: This file contains a high resolution time clock implementation.

class.name: microsec_clock
class.purpose: A clock providing microsecond level resolution.

description.para: A high precision clock that measures the local time at a resolution up to microseconds and adjusts to the resolution of the time system. For example, for the a library configuration with nano second resolution, the last 3 places of the fractional seconds will always be 000 since there are 1000 nano-seconds in a micro second.

method.name: local_time
method.purpose: return a local time object for the given zone, based on computer clock

method.name: local_time
method.purpose: Returns the local time based on computer clock settings.

method.name: universal_time
method.purpose: Returns the UTC time based on computer settings.

enum.name: month_format_spec
enum.purpose: Enum for distinguishing parsing and formatting options.

enum.name: ymd_order_spec
enum.purpose: Enum for distinguishing the order of Month, Day, & Year.

description.para: Enum for distinguishing the order in which Month, Day, & Year will appear in a date string

header.name: boost/date_time/period.hpp
header.para: This file contain the implementation of the period abstraction. This is basically the same idea as a range. Although this class is intended for use in the time library, it is pretty close to general enough for other numeric uses.

class.name: period
class.purpose: Provides generalized period type useful in date-time systems.

description.para: This template uses a class to represent a time point within the period and another class to represent a duration. As a result, this class is not appropriate for use when the number and duration representation are the same (eg: in the regular number domain).

A period can be specified by providing either the begining point and a duration or the begining point and the end point( end is NOT part of the period but 1 unit past it. A period will be "invalid" if either end_point <= begin_point or the given duration is <= 0. Any valid period will return false for is_null().

Zero length periods are also considered invalid. Zero length periods are periods where the begining and end points are the same, or, the given duration is zero. For a zero length period, the last point will be one unit less than the begining point.
In the case that the begin and last are the same, the period has a length of one unit.
The best way to handle periods is usually to provide a begining point and a duration. So, day1 + 7 days is a week period which includes all of the first day and 6 more days (eg: Sun to Sat).

method.name: begin
method.purpose: Return the first element in the period.

method.name: end
method.purpose: Return one past the last element.

method.name: last
method.purpose: Return the last item in the period.

method.name: length
method.purpose: Return the length of the period.

method.name: is_null
method.purpose: True if period is ill formed (length is zero or less)

method.name: operator==
method.purpose: Equality operator.

method.name: operator<
method.purpose: Strict as defined by rhs.last <= lhs.last.

method.name: shift
method.purpose: Shift the start and end by the specified amount.

description.para: Expands the size of the period by the duration on both ends.

method.name: contains
method.purpose: True if the point is inside the period, zero length periods contain no points.

method.name: contains
method.purpose: True if this period fully contains (or equals) the other period.

method.name: intersects
method.purpose: True if the periods overlap in any way.

method.name: is_adjacent
method.purpose: True if periods are next to each other without a gap.

method.name: is_before
method.purpose: True if all of the period is prior to the passed point or end <= t.

method.name: is_after
method.purpose: True if all of the period is prior or t < start.

method.name: intersection
method.purpose: Returns the period of intersection or invalid range no intersection.

method.name: merge
method.purpose: Returns the union of intersecting periods -- or null period.

method.name: span
method.purpose: Combine two periods with earliest start and latest end.

description.para: Combines two periods and any gap between them such that start = min(p1.start, p2.start) end = max(p1.end , p2.end) [---p1---) [---p2---) result: [-----------p3----------) *

constructor.purpose: create a period from begin to last eg: [begin,end)

description.para: If end <= begin then the period will be invalid

constructor.purpose: create a period as [begin, begin+len)

description.para: If len is <= 0 then the period will be invalid

class.name: period_formatter
class.purpose: Not a facet, but a class used to specify and control period formats.

description.para:
Provides settings for the following:
period_separator -- default '/'
period_open_start_delimeter -- default '['
period_open_range_end_delimeter -- default ')'
period_closed_range_end_delimeter -- default ']'
display_as_open_range, display_as_closed_range -- default closed_range

Thus the default formatting for a period is as follows: [period.start()/period.last()] * So for a typical date_period this would be [2004-Jan-04/2004-Feb-01] * where the date formatting is controlled by the date facet

method.name: put_period_separator
method.purpose: Puts the characters between period elements into stream -- default is /.

method.name: put_period_start_delimeter
method.purpose: Puts the period start characters into stream -- default is [.

method.name: put_period_end_delimeter
method.purpose: Puts the period end characters into stream as controled by open/closed range setting.

method.name: range_option
method.purpose: Reset the range_option control.

method.name: put_period
method.purpose: Generic code to output a period -- no matter the period type.

description.para: This generic code will output any period using a facet to to output the 'elements'. For example, in the case of a date_period the elements will be instances of a date which will be formatted according the to setup in the passed facet parameter.

The steps for formatting a period are always the same:
put the start delimiter
put start element
put the separator
put either last or end element depending on range settings
put end delimeter depending on range settings

Thus for a typical date period the result might look like this: [March 01, 2004/June 07, 2004] <-- closed range [March 01, 2004/June 08, 2004) <-- open range
*

constructor.purpose: Constructor that sets up period formatter options -- default should suffice most cases.

class.name: period_parser
class.purpose: Not a facet, but a class used to specify and control period parsing.

description.para:
Provides settings for the following:
period_separator -- default '/'
period_open_start_delimeter -- default '['
period_open_range_end_delimeter -- default ')'
period_closed_range_end_delimeter -- default ']'
display_as_open_range, display_as_closed_range -- default closed_range
For a typical date_period, the contents of the input stream would be [2004-Jan-04/2004-Feb-01] * where the date format is controlled by the date facet

method.name: get_period
method.purpose: Generic code to parse a period -- no matter the period type.

description.para: This generic code will parse any period using a facet to to get the 'elements'. For example, in the case of a date_period the elements will be instances of a date which will be parsed according the to setup in the passed facet parameter.

The steps for parsing a period are always the same:
consume the start delimiter
get start element
consume the separator
get either last or end element depending on range settings
consume the end delimeter depending on range settings

Thus for a typical date period the contents of the input stream might look like this: [March 01, 2004/June 07, 2004] <-- closed range [March 01, 2004/June 08, 2004) <-- open range
*

constructor.purpose: Constructor that sets up period parser options.

method.name: consume_delim
method.purpose: throws ios_base::failure if delimiter and parsed data do not match

class.purpose: Class that provides generic formmatting ostream formatting for special values.

description.para: This class provides for the formmating of special values to an output stream. In particular, it produces strings for the values of negative and positive infinity as well as not_a_date_time.
While not a facet, this class is used by the date and time facets for formatting special value types.

data-member.name: default_special_value_names
data-member.purpose: Storage for the strings used to indicate special values.

constructor.purpose: Construct special values formatter using default strings.

description.para: Default strings are not-a-date-time -infinity +infinity

constructor.purpose: Construct special values formatter from array of strings.

class.name: special_values_parser
class.purpose: Class for special_value parsing.

description.para:

not_a_date_time
neg_infin
pod_infin
min_date_time
max_date_time

method.name: sv_strings
method.purpose: Replace special value strings.

method.name: match
method.purpose: Sets match_results.current_match to the corresponding special_value or -1.

constructor.purpose: Creates a special_values_parser with the default set of "sv_strings".
Creates a special_values_parser using a user defined set of element strings.

function.name: convert_string_type
function.purpose: Converts a string from one value_type to another.

description.para: Converts a wstring to a string (or a string to wstring). If both template parameters are of same type, a copy of the input string is returned.

method.name: has_remaining
method.purpose: Returns true if more characters were parsed than was necessary.

description.para: Should be used in conjunction with last_char() to get the remaining character.

struct.name: string_parse_tree
struct.purpose: Recursive data structure to allow efficient parsing of various strings.

description.para: This class provides a quick lookup by building what amounts to a tree data structure. It also features a match function which can can handle nasty input interators by caching values as it recurses the tree so that it can backtrack as needed.

method.name: match
method.purpose: Recursive function that finds a matching string in the tree.

description.para: Must check match_results::has_remaining() after match() is called. This is required so the user can determine if stream iterator is already pointing to the expected character or not (match() might advance sitr to next char in stream).

A parse_match_result that has been returned from a failed match attempt can be sent in to the match function of a different string_parse_tree to attempt a match there. Use the iterators for the partially consumed stream, the parse_match_result object, and '0' for the level parameter.

Must check match_results::has_remaining() after match() is called. This is required so the user can determine if stream iterator is already pointing to the expected character or not (match() might advance sitr to next char in stream).

Parameter "starting_point" designates where the numbering begins. A starting_point of zero will start the numbering at zero (Sun=0, Mon=1, ...) were a starting_point of one starts the numbering at one (Jan=1, Feb=2, ...). The default is zero, negative vaules are not allowed

function.name: gather_month_strings

description.para: The locale to use when gathering the strings
True(default) to gather short strings, false for long strings.

function.purpose: This function gathers up all the month strings from a std::locale.

description.para: Using the time_put facet, this function creates a collection of all the month strings from a locale. This is handy when building custom date parsers or formatters that need to be localized.

returns.para: A vector of strings containing the strings in order. eg: Jan, Feb, Mar, etc.

function.name: gather_weekday_strings

description.para: The locale to use when gathering the strings
True(default) to gather short strings, false for long strings.

function.purpose: This function gathers up all the weekday strings from a std::locale.

description.para: Using the time_put facet, this function creates a collection of all the weekday strings from a locale starting with the string for 'Sunday'. This is handy when building custom date parsers or formatters that need to be localized.

returns.para: A vector of strings containing the weekdays in order. eg: Sun, Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat

header.name: boost/date_time/time.hpp
header.para: This file contains the interface for the time associated classes.

class.name: base_time
class.purpose: Representation of a precise moment in time, including the date.

description.para: This class is a skeleton for the interface of a temporal type with a resolution that is higher than a day. It is intended that this class be the base class and that the actual time class be derived using the BN pattern. In this way, the derived class can make decisions such as 'should there be a default constructor' and what should it set its value to, should there be optional constructors say allowing only an time_durations that generate a time from a clock,etc. So, in fact multiple time types can be created for a time_system with different construction policies, and all of them can perform basic operations by only writing a copy constructor. Finally, compiler errors are also shorter.
The real behavior of the time class is provided by the time_system template parameter. This class must provide all the logic for addition, subtraction, as well as define all the interface types.
Optional bool parameter will return time zone as an offset (ie "+07:00"). Empty string is returned for classes that do not use a time_zone
Optional bool parameter will return time zone as an offset (ie "+07:00"). Empty string is returned for classes that do not use a time_zone

method.name: zone_as_posix_string
method.purpose: An empty string is returned for classes that do not use a time_zone.

method.name: is_not_a_date_time
method.purpose: check to see if date is not a value

method.name: is_infinity
method.purpose: check to see if date is one of the infinity values

method.name: is_pos_infinity
method.purpose: check to see if date is greater than all possible dates

method.name: is_neg_infinity
method.purpose: check to see if date is greater than all possible dates

method.name: is_special
method.purpose: check to see if time is a special value

method.name: operator==
method.purpose: Equality operator -- others generated by boost::equality_comparable.

method.name: operator<
method.purpose: Equality operator -- others generated by boost::less_than_comparable.

method.name: operator-
method.purpose: difference between two times

method.name: operator+
method.purpose: add date durations

method.name: operator-
method.purpose: subtract date durations

method.name: operator+
method.purpose: add time durations

method.name: operator-
method.purpose: subtract time durations

header.name: boost/date_time/time_clock.hpp
header.para: This file contains the interface for clock devices.

class.name: second_clock
class.purpose: A clock providing time level services based on C time_t capabilities.

description.para: This clock provides resolution to the 1 second level

method.name: universal_time
method.purpose: Get the current day in universal date as a ymd_type.

header.name: boost/date_time/time_defs.hpp
header.para: This file contains nice definitions for handling the resoluion of various time reprsentations.

enum.name: time_resolutions
enum.purpose: Defines some nice types for handling time level resolutions.

enum.name: dst_flags
enum.purpose: Flags for daylight savings or summer time.

class.name: time_duration
class.purpose: Represents some amount of elapsed time measure to a given resolution.

description.para: This class represents a standard set of capabilities for all counted time durations. Time duration implementations should derive from this class passing their type as the first template parameter. This design allows the subclass duration types to provide custom construction policies or other custom features not provided here.

method.name: hours
method.purpose: Returns number of hours in the duration.

method.name: minutes
method.purpose: Returns normalized number of minutes.

method.name: seconds
method.purpose: Returns normalized number of seconds (0..60)

method.name: total_seconds
method.purpose: Returns total number of seconds truncating any fractional seconds.

method.name: total_milliseconds
method.purpose: Returns total number of milliseconds truncating any fractional seconds.

method.name: total_nanoseconds
method.purpose: Returns total number of nanoseconds truncating any sub millisecond values.

method.name: total_microseconds
method.purpose: Returns total number of microseconds truncating any sub microsecond values.

method.name: fractional_seconds
method.purpose: Returns count of fractional seconds at given resolution.

method.name: operator-
method.purpose: unary- Allows for time_duration td = -td1

method.name: operator/=
method.purpose: Division operations on a duration with an integer.

method.name: operator*
method.purpose: Multiplication operations an a duration with an integer.

method.name: is_special
method.purpose: Is ticks_ a special value?

method.name: is_pos_infinity
method.purpose: Is duration pos-infinity.

method.name: is_neg_infinity
method.purpose: Is duration neg-infinity.

method.name: is_not_a_date_time
method.purpose: Is duration not-a-date-time.

method.name: get_rep
method.purpose: Used for special_values output.

constructor.purpose: Construct from another time_duration (Copy constructor)
Construct from special_values.

method.name: unit
method.purpose: Returns smallest representable duration.

method.name: ticks_per_second
method.purpose: Return the number of ticks in a second.

method.name: resolution
method.purpose: Provide the resolution of this duration type.

method.name: num_fractional_digits
method.purpose: Returns number of possible digits in fractional seconds.

class.name: subsecond_duration
class.purpose: Template for instantiating derived adjusting durations.

parameter.paramtype: \"The base duration resolution must be a multiple of the subsecond duration resolution"

description.para:
Facet used for format-based output of time types This class provides for the use of format strings to output times. In addition to the flags for formatting date elements, the following are the allowed format flags:
x X => default format - enables addition of more flags to default (ie. "%x %X %z")
f => fractional seconds ".123456"
F => fractional seconds or none: like frac sec but empty if frac sec == 0
s => seconds w/ fractional sec "02.123" (this is the same as "%S%f) - %S => seconds "02" - %z => abbreviated time zone "EDT" - %Z => full time zone name "Eastern Daylight Time"

method.purpose: Changes format for time_duration.

method.name: put
method.purpose: put function for time_duration

constructor.purpose: sets default formats for ptime, local_date_time, and time_duration

constructor.purpose: Constructor that takes a format string for a ptime.
sets default formats for ptime, local_date_time, and time_duration

description.para: First character may have been consumed during original parse attempt. Parameter 'c' should be a copy of that character. Throws ios_base::failure if parse fails.

class.name: time_itr

function.name: power
function.purpose: computes exponential math like 2^8 => 256, only works with positive integers

function.name: str_from_delimited_time_duration
function.purpose: Creates a time_duration object from a delimited string.

description.para: Expected format for string is "[-]h[h][:mm][:ss][.fff]". If the number of fractional digits provided is greater than the precision of the time duration type then the extra digits are truncated.
A negative duration will be created if the first character in string is a '-', all other '-' will be treated as delimiters. Accepted delimiters are "-:,.".

function.name: parse_delimited_time_duration
function.purpose: Creates a time_duration object from a delimited string.

description.para: Expected format for string is "[-]h[h][:mm][:ss][.fff]". If the number of fractional digits provided is greater than the precision of the time duration type then the extra digits are truncated.
A negative duration will be created if the first character in string is a '-', all other '-' will be treated as delimiters. Accepted delimiters are "-:,.".

function.name: split
function.purpose: Utility function to split appart string.

function.name: parse_undelimited_time_duration
function.purpose: Parse time duration part of an iso time of form: [-]hhmmss[.fff...] (eg: 120259.123 is 12 hours, 2 min, 59 seconds, 123000 microseconds)

function.name: parse_iso_time
function.purpose: Parse time string of form YYYYMMDDThhmmss where T is delimeter between date and time.

class.name: time_zone_base
class.purpose: Interface class for dynamic time zones.

description.para: This class represents the base interface for all timezone representations. Subclasses may provide different systems for identifying a particular zone. For example some may provide a geographical based zone construction while others may specify the offset from GMT. Another possible implementation would be to convert from POSIX timezone strings. Regardless of the construction technique, this is the interface that these time zone types must provide.
Note that this class is intended to be used as a shared resource (hence the derivation from boost::counted_base.

method.name: dst_zone_abbrev
method.purpose: String for the timezone when in daylight savings (eg: EDT)

method.name: std_zone_abbrev
method.purpose: String for the zone when not in daylight savings (eg: EST)

method.name: dst_zone_name
method.purpose: String for the timezone when in daylight savings (eg: Eastern Daylight Time)

method.name: std_zone_name
method.purpose: String for the zone when not in daylight savings (eg: Eastern Standard Time)

method.name: has_dst
method.purpose: True if zone uses daylight savings adjustments otherwise false.

method.name: dst_local_start_time
method.purpose: Local time that DST starts -- undefined if has_dst is false.

method.name: dst_local_end_time
method.purpose: Local time that DST ends -- undefined if has_dst is false.

method.name: base_utc_offset
method.purpose: Base offset from UTC for zone (eg: -07:30:00)

method.name: dst_offset
method.purpose: Adjustment forward or back made while DST is in effect.

method.name: to_posix_string
method.purpose: Returns a POSIX time_zone string for this object.

class.name: dst_adjustment_offsets
class.purpose: Structure which holds the time offsets associated with daylight savings time.

data-member.name: dst_adjust_
data-member.purpose: Amount DST adjusts the clock eg: plus one hour.

data-member.name: dst_start_offset_
data-member.purpose: Time past midnight on start transition day that dst starts.

data-member.name: dst_end_offset_
data-member.purpose: Time past midnight on end transition day that dst ends.

class.name: time_zone_names_base
class.purpose: Base type that holds various string names for timezone output.

description.para: Class that holds various types of strings used for timezones. For example, for the western United States there is the full name: Pacific Standard Time and the abbreviated name: PST. During daylight savings there are additional names: Pacific Daylight Time and PDT. CharT Allows class to support different character types

class.name: data_not_accessible
class.purpose: Exception thrown when tz database cannot locate requested data file.

class.name: bad_field_count
class.purpose: Exception thrown when tz database locates incorrect field structure in data file.

class.name: tz_db_base
class.purpose: Creates a database of time_zones from csv datafile.

description.para: The csv file containing the zone_specs used by the tz_db_base is intended to be customized by the library user. When customizing this file (or creating your own) the file must follow a specific format.
This first line is expected to contain column headings and is therefore not processed by the tz_db_base.

Each record (line) must have eleven fields. Some of those fields can be empty. Every field (even empty ones) must be enclosed in double-quotes. Ex: "America/Phoenix" <- string enclosed in quotes "" <- empty field
Some fields represent a length of time. The format of these fields must be: "{+|-}hh:mm[:ss]" <- length-of-time format Where the plus or minus is mandatory and the seconds are optional.

Since some time zones do not use daylight savings it is not always necessary for every field in a zone_spec to contain a value. All zone_specs must have at least ID and GMT offset. Zones that use daylight savings must have all fields filled except: STD ABBR, STD NAME, DST NAME. You should take note that DST ABBR is mandatory for zones that use daylight savings (see field descriptions for further details).
******* Fields and their description/details *********
ID: Contains the identifying string for the zone_spec. Any string will do as long as it's unique. No two ID's can be the same.
NOTE: The exact format/function names may vary - see local_time documentation for further details.

GMT offset: This is the number of hours added to utc to get the local time before any daylight savings adjustments are made. Some examples are: America/New_York offset -5 hours, & Africa/Cairo offset +2 hours. The format must follow the length-of-time format described above.
DST adjustment: The amount of time added to gmt_offset when daylight savings is in effect. The format must follow the length-of-time format described above.

DST Start Date rule: This is a specially formatted string that describes the day of year in which the transition take place. It holds three fields of it's own, separated by semicolons. The first field indicates the "nth" weekday of the month. The possible values are: 1 (first), 2 (second), 3 (third), 4 (fourth), 5 (fifth), and -1 (last). The second field indicates the day-of-week from 0-6 (Sun=0). The third field indicates the month from 1-12 (Jan=1).
Examples are: "-1;5;9"="Last Friday of September", "2;1;3"="Second Monday of March"

Start time: Start time is the number of hours past midnight, on the day of the start transition, the transition takes place. More simply put, the time of day the transition is made (in 24 hours format). The format must follow the length-of-time format described above with the exception that it must always be positive.
DST End date rule: See DST Start date rule. The difference here is this is the day daylight savings ends (transition to STD).
End time: Same as Start time.

method.name: load_from_stream
method.purpose: Process csv data file, may throw exceptions.

description.para: May throw bad_field_count exceptions

method.name: load_from_file
method.purpose: Process csv data file, may throw exceptions.

description.para: May throw data_not_accessible, or bad_field_count exceptions

method.name: add_record
method.purpose: returns true if record successfully added to map

description.para: Takes a region name in the form of "America/Phoenix", and a time_zone object for that region. The id string must be a unique name that does not already exist in the database.

method.name: time_zone_from_region
method.purpose: Returns a time_zone object built from the specs for the given region.

description.para: Returns a time_zone object built from the specs for the given region. If region does not exist a local_time::record_not_found exception will be thrown

method.name: region_list
method.purpose: Returns a vector of strings holding the time zone regions in the database.

constructor.purpose: Constructs an empty database.

method.name: parse_rules
method.purpose: parses rule specs for transition day rules

method.name: get_week_num
method.purpose: helper function for parse_rules()

method.name: split_rule_spec
method.purpose: splits the [start|end]_date_rule string into 3 ints

method.name: parse_string
method.purpose: Take a line from the csv, turn it into a time_zone_type.

description.para: Take a line from the csv, turn it into a time_zone_type, and add it to the map. Zone_specs in csv file are expected to have eleven fields that describe the time zone. Returns true if zone_spec successfully added to database

class.name: wrapping_int
class.purpose: A wrapping integer used to support time durations (WARNING: only instantiate with a signed type)

description.para: In composite date and time types this type is used to wrap at the day boundary. Ex: A wrapping_int<short, 10> will roll over after nine, and roll under below zero. This gives a range of [0,9]
NOTE: it is strongly recommended that wrapping_int2 be used instead of wrapping_int as wrapping_int is to be depricated at some point soon.
Also Note that warnings will occur if instantiated with an unsigned type. Only a signed type should be used!

method.name: as_int
method.purpose: Explicit converion method.

method.name: add
method.purpose: Add, return number of wraps performed.

description.para: The sign of the returned value will indicate which direction the wraps went. Ex: add a negative number and wrapping under could occur, this would be indicated by a negative return value. If wrapping over took place, a positive value would be returned

method.name: subtract
method.purpose: Subtract will return '+d' if wrapping under took place ('d' is the number of wraps)

description.para: The sign of the returned value will indicate which direction the wraps went (positive indicates wrap under, negative indicates wrap over). Ex: subtract a negative number and wrapping over could occur, this would be indicated by a negative return value. If wrapping under took place, a positive value would be returned.

constructor.purpose: Add, return true if wrapped.

class.name: wrapping_int2
class.purpose: A wrapping integer used to wrap around at the top (WARNING: only instantiate with a signed type)

description.para: Bad name, quick impl to fix a bug -- fix later!! This allows the wrap to restart at a value other than 0.

method.name: as_int
method.purpose: Explicit converion method.

method.name: add
method.purpose: Add, return number of wraps performed.

description.para: The sign of the returned value will indicate which direction the wraps went. Ex: add a negative number and wrapping under could occur, this would be indicated by a negative return value. If wrapping over took place, a positive value would be returned

method.name: subtract
method.purpose: Subtract will return '-d' if wrapping under took place ('d' is the number of wraps)

description.para: The sign of the returned value will indicate which direction the wraps went. Ex: subtract a negative number and wrapping over could occur, this would be indicated by a positive return value. If wrapping under took place, a negative value would be returned
If initializing value is out of range of [wrap_min, wrap_max], value will be initialized to closest of min or max

struct.name: year_month_day_base
struct.purpose: Allow rapid creation of ymd triples of different types.

constructor.purpose: A basic constructor.
